content.text:
# Scheduled monuments in Kent

There are 689 scheduled monuments in the county of Kent, England. These protected sites date in some cases from the Neolithic period, and include barrows, artillery forts, ruined abbeys, castles, and Iron Age hill forts.
In the United Kingdom, the scheduling of monuments was first initiated to ensure the preservation of "nationally important" archaeological sites and historic buildings. Protection is given to scheduled monuments under the Ancient Monuments and Archaeological Areas Act 1979.
Notable scheduled monuments in Kent
This is a partial list of scheduled monuments in Kent.
{| class="wikitable sortable"
!class="unsortable"|Image
! Name
! Location
! Date
! class="unsortable"|Notes
|-
|
| Canterbury Castle
|
| 11th century
| One of the three original royal castles of Kent, all built soon after the Battle of Hastings.
|-
|
| Chestnuts Long Barrow
|
| Early Neolithic era
|  Chambered long barrow. Belongs to the group of burial tombs known as the Medway Megaliths.
|-
| |
| Coldrum Long Barrow
|
|Early Neolithic era
| Also known as the "Coldrum Stones". Belongs to the group of burial tombs known as the Medway Megaliths.
|-
| |
| Dover Castle
|
| 11th century
| One of the three original royal castles of Kent. Considered the most significant defensive castle in the history of England.
|-
|-
| |
| Eynsford Castle
|
| 11th century AD
|  Ruined medieval fortification. An early Norman castle.
|-
|-
| |
| Greyfriars, Canterbury
|
| Early 13th century
| The first Franciscan friary in England.
|-
|-
| |
| Lower Mill, Woodchurch
|
| 1820
| A surviving early 19th century smock mill, which is a type of windmill that takes its name from its similarity to smocks worn by farmers during that era.
|-
| |
| Oldbury Camp
|
| 1st century BC
| The largest Iron Age hill fort in south-eastern England.
|-
|
|  Richborough Castle
|
|   1st century AD
|  Roman Saxon Shore fort.
|-
|
| Rochester Castle
|
| 1087–1089 AD
| One of the three original royal castles of Kent. The 12th-century keep is one of the best preserved in England or France.
|-
|
| St Augustine's Abbey
|
| 598 AD
| Benedictine monastery founded by St Augustine. Originally dedicated to St Peter and St Paul. Renamed after Augustine's death.
|-
|
| St Mary's Church, Eastwell
|
| 15th century
| Ruined parish church. It is also a designated Grade II listed building.
|-
|
| Upnor Castle
|
| 1559–1567
| Rare example of an Elizabethan artillery fort.
|}
